page.title: 04LANDSCAPE AROUND OSSINGTON.
page.content: This very{rural}landscape with its many wooded areas is inhabited by various species of{wildlife,}such as {rabbits, hares, foxes}and{badgers.}It has a few gently sloping gradients, but is mainly flat, so much so that it was the site of{Ossington aerodrome}in the{second world war.}The runways have almost gone now returning the land to farmland again, but one or two{air {raid shelters}still remain. A number of exotic trees are now growing wild, where they used to be enclosed in gardens belonging to the old hall which has since been demolished. There is also part of a {Haha}remaining here, this is a{sunken {fence bounding the garden. The lake at Ossington is mainly used as a base for wild duck, and a few eels and fish are to be found there.
